revised_title: Selective Breeding Improves Laboratory Propagation of Insect Parasites
tldr: The article discusses the application of selective breeding methods to improve the laboratory propagation of insect parasites, specifically Microplectron fuscipennis Zett. Through selective breeding, laboratory production allowed the distribution of 889 million parasites over the spruce sawfly-infested area in Canada. The study found that selection in breeding lines led to a continuous decrease in the number of sterile males, an increase in the mean number of offspring per mother, and a reduction in variability of development, oviposition, and adult life length.
